elements.content: In this work, the coexistence of In­(III) and K­(I) induces a rapid crystal growth of single crystals of heterometallic metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [In0.5K­(3-qlc)­Cl1.5(H2O)0.5]2n (1) and [InK­(ox)2­(H2O)4] n (2) (3-Hqlc = quinoline-3-carboxylic acid; H2ox = oxalic acid). Remarkably, with the help of achiral 3-Hqlc, compound 1 represents the chiral interpenetrating p-block heterometallic MOFs with helical chain along the 43 screw axis, while compound 2 possesses a highly symmetric (4,4,4)-connected topology network with a Schläfli symbol of (42·83·10)­(42·84). Consideration of two different organic ligands viz. 3-Hqlc and H2ox constructed heterometallic MOFs with different geometrical dimensions of unit cells, their influences on luminescence and photovoltaic properties are studied. Compounds 1 and 2 show tunable luminescence from blue to yellow and white by varying the temperature in the solid state. Encouraged by the UV–visible absorption and HOMO–LUMO energy states matched for sensitizing TiO2, the two compounds are employed in combination with N719 in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) to compensate for absorption in the region of ultraviolet and blue-violet. Under optimized conditions, the DSSCs devices using cosensitizers of 1/N719 and 2/N719 display an overall conversion efficiency of 8.07% and 7.42%, which is 22.09% and 12.25% higher than that of a device solely sensitized by N719 (6.61%). Consequently, both of the two compounds could serve as excellent photosensitizers and application in luminescence sensors and DSSCs.

elements.content: The strategy of synthesis cooperative crystallization of indium­(III)−potassium­(I) metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), resulting from the combination of luminescence and DSSCs, expands the pool of the chirality of the compounds by achiral units and pave a way for realizing new applications of heterometallic MOFs.
elements.clean_text: The strategy of synthesis cooperative crystallization of indium(III)-potassium(I) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), resulting from the combination of luminescence and DSSCs, expands the pool of the chirality of the compounds by achiral units and pave a way for realizing new applications of heterometallic MOFs.

elements.content: Life is a typical chiral system, and chiral phenomena are ubiquitous in nature from the macroscopic to the molecular level. Currently chiral solid materials have been a frontier research field, appealing for nonlinear optics, biomimetic chemistry, enantiomerically selective separation, and catalysis. Meanwhile, heterometallic metal organic frameworks (MOFs) hold great promise for the preparation of chiral materials due to their facile tailoring structures formed by metal ions or clusters (denoted secondary building units, SBUs) and organic ligands. Traditionally, the most convenient method for the synthesis of chiral compounds is using chiral molecules as ligands by introducing their inherent chirality into the frameworks via a “chirality conservation” process. However, considering the limitation of the chiral pool and the high cost of chiral ligands, the search for novel chiral solid materials from achiral precursors, which can construct homochiral MOFs or a pair of enantiomers by means of spontaneous resolution, is extremely desirable. Therefore, such investigation on appropriate achiral precursors is expected to propel this emerging field further into a new realm in which far more chiral heterometallic MOFs may be accessed. Moreover, it should be noted that most of reported chiral heterometallic MOFs focused on the d–f metal-based frameworks, while chiral p-block heterometallic MOFs were rarely explored.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Life is a typical chiral system, and chiral phenomena are ubiquitous in nature from the macroscopic to the molecular level. Currently chiral solid materials have been a frontier research field, appealing for nonlinear optics, biomimetic chemistry, enantiomerically selective separation, and catalysis. Meanwhile, heterometallic metal organic frameworks (MOFs) hold great promise for the preparation of chiral materials due to their facile tailoring structures formed by metal ions or clusters (denoted secondary building units, SBUs) and organic ligands. Traditionally, the most convenient method for the synthesis of chiral compounds is using chiral molecules as ligands by introducing their inherent chirality into the frameworks via a "chirality conservation" process. However, considering the limitation of the chiral pool and the high cost of chiral ligands, the search for novel chiral solid materials from achiral precursors, which can construct homochiral MOFs or a pair of enantiomers by means of spontaneous resolution, is extremely desirable. Therefore, such investigation on appropriate achiral precursors is expected to propel this emerging field further into a new realm in which far more chiral heterometallic MOFs may be accessed. Moreover, it should be noted that most of reported chiral heterometallic MOFs focused on the d-f metal-based frameworks, while chiral p-block heterometallic MOFs were rarely explored.

elements.content: Indeed among all metal ions, the p-block MOFs featuring the intrinsic properties have potential applications in catalysis, gas absorption/separations, light emitting diodes, cell imaging, and drug delivery. Specifically, In­(III) organic frameworks (InOFs) with a combination of favorable optical and electrochemical properties tend to be suitable for conducting further applications. In this context, seeking a new approach to design and construct of functional InOFs material is extremely necessary. Inspired by this, we may expect to integrate both chirality and p-block heterometallic MOFs into one single system not only for fascinating topological structures but also for versatile applications.

Specifically, In(III) organic frameworks (InOFs) with a combination of favorable optical and electrochemical properties tend to be suitable for conducting further applications. In this context, seeking a new approach to design and construct of functional InOFs material is extremely necessary. Inspired by this, we may expect to integrate both chirality and p-block heterometallic MOFs into one single system not only for fascinating topological structures but also for versatile applications.

elements.content: In this study, we discovered that the presence of K­(I) can induce the crystallization of otherwise noncrystallizable InOFs. It is an effective strategy to construct heterometallic MOFs material where COO–-affinitive In­(III) ions bind only to O atoms, while K­(I)-based units also bind to pyridyl N-centers. Meanwhile, in order to seek optimal achiral precursors to accommodate chiral heterometallic MOFs, two kinds of carboxylic acid ligands with different molecular characters, viz. asymmetric 3-Hqlc and symmetric H2ox are used to synthesize two heterometallic In–K–OFs, [In0.5K­(3-qlc)­Cl1.5­(H2O)0.5]2n (1) and [InK­(ox)2­(H2O)4] n (2) (3-Hqlc = quinoline-3-carboxylic acid; H2ox = oxalic acid) under hydro­(solvo)­thermal conditions. Remarkably, compound 1 features the unusual chiral interpenetrating p-block heterometallic MOFs with a helical chain along the 43 screw axis, while compound 2 possesses a highly symmetric (4,4,4)-connected topology network with a Schläfli symbol of (42·83·10)­(42·84). The structure of compound 2 has been reported by Audebrand et al., but they directly use KNO3 as the metal source rather than KOH as additive. Herein, we mainly talk about the choice of suitable ligands and reveal that asymmetric ligands might be more compatible for the synthesis of chiral compounds. Moreover, the design strategy for the synthesis of heterometallic MOFs can vary significantly depending on the intended applications. The metal nodes, organic linkers, as well as metal–ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) emission within heterometallic MOFs all can potentially generate luminescence. Such unique characteristics make heterometallic MOFs material promising candidates for luminescent sensors. Meanwhile, heterometallic MOFs have large conjugated π electronic systems, which are capable of light collection and subsequent energy transport over long distances. Considering N719 with low utilization in the region of short wavelength, cosensitization is considered to be a more promising way. Compared with traditional cosensitizers, heterometallic MOFs have the following advantages: (1) MOFs with strong absorption in the blue-violet spectral region could extend the light harvesting spectrum. (2) Due to large surface and high porosity, dye molecules might have been adsorbed on the large interior surfaces of MOFs to enhance efficient light harvesting. Therefore, the conjunction of heterometallic MOFs with dual-functional luminescence and photovoltaic properties as sensitizers has also been preliminarily explored.

elements.content: All materials and reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets using a Nicolet Avatar-360 infrared spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 element analyzer. The thermal analyses were performed on a ZRY-2P thermogravimetric analysis under a flow of air from room temperature to 700 °C. The solid-state CD measurement on an MOS-450 instrument was performed on the solid material in the KCl plate. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using a PANalytical X-ray diffractometer. UV–visible absorption spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 20 spectrometer. The solid-state photoluminescence analyses were carried out on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was measured with a electrochemical workstation (CHI660D, Chenhua, Shanghai) using a three-electrode cell with a Pt working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode, and a saturated calomel reference electrode in saturated KCl solution. The supporting electrolyte was 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAPF6, Fluka, electrochemical grade) in CH3CN as the solvent. Photocurrent–photovoltage (J–V) curves were recorded by a Keithley model 2400 digital source meter using a mask with an aperture area of 0.16 cm–2. The incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) was measured on an EQE/IPCE spectral response system (Newport). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded by CHI660D Electrochemical Analyzer (Chenhua, China).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All materials and reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets using a Nicolet Avatar-360 infrared spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 element analyzer. The thermal analyses were performed on a ZRY-2P thermogravimetric analysis under a flow of air from room temperature to 700 °C. The solid-state CD measurement on an MOS-450 instrument was performed on the solid material in the KCl plate. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using a PANalytical X-ray diffractometer. UV-visible absorption spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 20 spectrometer. The solid-state photoluminescence analyses were carried out on an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was measured with a electrochemical workstation (CHI660D, Chenhua, Shanghai) using a three-electrode cell with a Pt working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode, and a saturated calomel reference electrode in saturated KCl solution. The supporting electrolyte was 0.1 M tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAPF6, Fluka, electrochemical grade) in CH3CN as the solvent. Photocurrent-photovoltage (J-V) curves were recorded by a Keithley model 2400 digital source meter using a mask with an aperture area of 0.16 cm-2. The incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) was measured on an EQE/IPCE spectral response system (Newport). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded by CHI660D Electrochemical Analyzer (Chenhua, China).

elements.content: Single crystals of compound 1 were obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of InCl3 (0.0442 g) and 3-Hqlc (0.0220 g) with a molar ratio of 2:1 in H2O (8 mL) and adjusted to pH = 6.5 with an aqueous solution of KOH. While being stirred for 30 min in air, it was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 120 h. After slowly being cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature (yield 71.2% based on 3-Hqlc). Elemental analysis calcd for [C20H14Cl3N2­O5InK2 (M r : 661.70)]: C, 36.27; H,2.12; N,4.23%; found: C, 36.25; H, 2.16; N, 4.25%. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1) for 1: 3472 (br, s), 3223 (m), 1622 (m), 1598 (s), 1418 (vs), 1312 (m), 1140 (w), 956 (w), 894 (w), 822 (vs), 786 (vs), 738 (m), 648 (w), 595 (m), 533 (w), 471 (w).

Synthesis of [InK(ox)2(H2O)4] n  (2)

Colorless block crystals of compound 2 were obtained by solvothermal reaction of In(NO3)3 (0.0602 g) and H2ox (0.0091 g) with a molar ratio of 2:1 in 5 mL of DMF/CH3CH2OH/H2O (1:2:2 mL) and adjusted to pH = 6.0 with an aqueous solution of KOH. While being stirred for 30 min in air, it was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 120 h. After being slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature (yield 65.4% based on H2ox). Elemental analysis calcd for [C4H8O12InK (M r : 402.02)]: C,11.94; H,1.99%; found: C,11.92; H,1.96%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1) for 2: 3423 (br, s), 1580 (vs), 1409 (vs), 1026 (w), 964 (w), 886 (w), 844 (w), 776 (m), 698 (w), 675 (w), 526 (m), 448 (w).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction for the two compounds were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP or a Siemens SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystal structures were resolved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software. Anisotropic thermal parameters were refined to all of the non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode except water molecules. Water hydrogen atoms were located from different map. The H–O distances are restrained. Crystallographic data and structural refinement for compound 1 are listed in . CCDC reference number 1416588 for 1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles of the two compounds are listed as Table S1 (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction for the two compounds were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP or a Siemens SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystal structures were resolved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software. Anisotropic thermal parameters were refined to all of the non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode except water molecules. Water hydrogen atoms were located from different map. The H-O distances are restrained. Crystallographic data and structural refinement for compound 1 are listed in . CCDC reference number 1416588 for 1. Selected bond lengths and bond angles of the two compounds are listed as Table S1 (Supporting Information).

elements.content: On the basis of the advantages of MOFs as cosensitizers, compounds 1 and 2 respectively with N719 were fabricated photoanodes by the following procedure, application in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of Devices

On the basis of the advantages of MOFs as cosensitizers, compounds 1 and 2 respectively with N719 were fabricated photoanodes by the following procedure, application in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).

elements.content: Initially, FTO substrate (90% transmittance in the visible, 15 Ω per square, purchased from NSG, Japan) was treated by 20 mM TiCl4 aqueous solution in order to reduce the recombination between FTO and electrolyte. Subsequently, the TiO2 paste was cast onto the FTO substrate by the screen-printing method, followed by drying at 100 °C for 5 min, and this process was repeated six times, then followed by sintering at 500 °C for 15 min in air to obtain a transparent TiO2 photoelectrode with the thickness of ca. 10 μm. Next, the cosensitized 1/N719 and 2/N719 photoanodes were prepared by immersing the obtained mesoporous TiO2 photoelectrode into 0.3 mM compound 1 or compound 2 solution in absolute ethanol for 2 h and washed with ethanol and dried with a blower and then the photoanodes were further immersed in 0.3 mM N719 solution in absolute ethanol for 12 h, and then washed with ethanol and dried with the blower again. The single N719 sensitized photoanode was prepared by only immersing the TiO2 photoelectrode into 0.3 mM N719 solution in absolute ethanol for 14 h in order to demonstrate the effect of MOFs in the cosensitized photoanodes.

elements.content: It should be pointed out that the electrolyte used in this work was 0.5 M LiI, 0.05 M I2, 0.1 M tert-butylpyridine in a 1:1 (volume ratio) of acetonitrile-propylene carbonate. The platinum counter electrode was prepared by depositing H2PtCl6 paste onto the FTO glass substrates and then sintering at 450 °C for 30 min. All the cells were assembled by sandwiching the electrolyte between the dye-sensitized photoanode and the counter electrode. They were held together using mini-binder clips.

elements.content: Both of the compounds adopt an unusual coordination mode; namely, the third main group In­(III) ion and the first main group K­(I) ion are cooperatively performed in coordination process. More importantly, the In­(III) ion and K­(I) ion are interconnected by chloride ions and oxygen atoms to afford a heterometallic cluster as shown in . Throughout the CCDC database and the literature, three typical kinds of SBU-based architectures of In­(III) centers have been observed, including eight-coordinated In­(CO2)4 monomers, infinite In­(OH) (CO2)2 chains, and six-connected In3O­(CO2)6 trimers. Herein, the discovery of the heterometallic cluster helps to expand SBUs in the MOFs system. Meanwhile, adopting two different ligands viz., 3-Hqlc and H2ox to construct chiral heterometallic MOFs reveals that asymmetric organic ligands are more applicable as achiral precursors.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Both of the compounds adopt an unusual coordination mode; namely, the third main group In(III) ion and the first main group K(I) ion are cooperatively performed in coordination process. More importantly, the In(III) ion and K(I) ion are interconnected by chloride ions and oxygen atoms to afford a heterometallic cluster as shown in . Throughout the CCDC database and the literature, three typical kinds of SBU-based architectures of In(III) centers have been observed, including eight-coordinated In(CO2)4 monomers, infinite In(OH) (CO2)2 chains, and six-connected In3O(CO2)6 trimers. Herein, the discovery of the heterometallic cluster helps to expand SBUs in the MOFs system. Meanwhile, adopting two different ligands viz., 3-Hqlc and H2ox to construct chiral heterometallic MOFs reveals that asymmetric organic ligands are more applicable as achiral precursors.

elements.clean_text: 1  Reaction Routes of Compounds 1 and 2

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group P43212, and the asymmetry unit contains a half In­(III) ion, one K­(I) ion, one 3-qlc– anion, one and a half Cl– anions, and a half coordinated water molecule. The central In­(III) cation is located in a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramid by four carboxyl oxygen atoms from two individual 3-qlc– ligands, three coordinated Cl– anions. The bond distances of In–O are 2.262(4) and 2.427(3) Å, and the In–Cl bond lengths are 2.448(2) and 2.469(1) Å, respectively. Interestingly, the K­(I) center has a seven-coordinated single-capped octahedron geometry with three carboxyl oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from four 3-qlc– ligands, one coordinated H2O molecule, and two coordinated Cl– anions. The K–O bond lengths are 2.789(5)–3.020(4) Å, the K–N bond length is 2.958(5) Å, and the K–Cl bond lengths are 3.178(2)–3.405(2) Å, which are all within the normal ranges found in other K­(I) cation compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description for Compound 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group P43212, and the asymmetry unit contains a half In(III) ion, one K(I) ion, one 3-qlc- anion, one and a half Cl- anions, and a half coordinated water molecule. The central In(III) cation is located in a slightly distorted pentagonal bipyramid by four carboxyl oxygen atoms from two individual 3-qlc- ligands, three coordinated Cl- anions. The bond distances of In-O are 2.262(4) and 2.427(3) Å, and the In-Cl bond lengths are 2.448(2) and 2.469(1) Å, respectively. Interestingly, the K(I) center has a seven-coordinated single-capped octahedron geometry with three carboxyl oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom from four 3-qlc- ligands, one coordinated H2O molecule, and two coordinated Cl- anions. The K-O bond lengths are 2.789(5)-3.020(4) Å, the K-N bond length is 2.958(5) Å, and the K-Cl bond lengths are 3.178(2)-3.405(2) Å, which are all within the normal ranges found in other K(I) cation compounds.

elements.content: Each 3-qlc– anion links four K­(I) cations and one In­(III) cation in μ5-η2:η3:η1 coordination mode. Meanwhile, because of the existing coordinated water molecule, the 3-qlc– anion and water molecule alternately bridge one In­(III) and two K­(I) cations into an infinite right-handed 43 helical chain with a pitch length of 14.767 Å along the c axis (a,b), which is consistent with the compound crystallizing in the P43212 space group, and the Flack parameter is near zero (). Each helical chain serves as a SBU and is further linked to its four adjacent neighbors with the same handedness in two orthogonal directions through 3-qlc– anion and water molecule links, generating a homochiral 3D framework (c). More especially, the whole framework can be reduced to 2-fold interpenetration 3D net under the circumstance of the metal viewed as the node and the 3-qlc– ligands and water molecule as linkers (d). After careful observation, we find the existence of the coordinated Cl– anions renders a peculiar type of embedded in the 2-fold interpenetration 3D net (e). It links the K­(I) cation and In­(III) cation to give another 3D net, which situates between the 2-fold interpenetration 3D net. Thus, the superimposing of 3D + 3D→ 3D structure of 1 constitutes a novel framework (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: Each 3-qlc- anion links four K(I) cations and one In(III) cation in μ5-η2:η3:η1 coordination mode. Meanwhile, because of the existing coordinated water molecule, the 3-qlc- anion and water molecule alternately bridge one In(III) and two K(I) cations into an infinite right-handed 43 helical chain with a pitch length of 14.767 Å along the c axis (a,b), which is consistent with the compound crystallizing in the P43212 space group, and the Flack parameter is near zero (). Each helical chain serves as a SBU and is further linked to its four adjacent neighbors with the same handedness in two orthogonal directions through 3-qlc- anion and water molecule links, generating a homochiral 3D framework (c). More especially, the whole framework can be reduced to 2-fold interpenetration 3D net under the circumstance of the metal viewed as the node and the 3-qlc- ligands and water molecule as linkers (d). After careful observation, we find the existence of the coordinated Cl- anions renders a peculiar type of embedded in the 2-fold interpenetration 3D net (e). It links the K(I) cation and In(III) cation to give another 3D net, which situates between the 2-fold interpenetration 3D net. Thus, the superimposing of 3D + 3D→ 3D structure of 1 constitutes a novel framework (Figure S2).

It should be pointed out the structure of compound 2 has been briefly reported previously, but herein the description is for comprehensive comparison. Compound 2 adopts the eight-coordinated In­(CO)8 monomers with the bridging-O connecting eight-coordinated KO4(CO)4 monomers (). Similarly, each independent H2ox molecule is coordinated by two K­(I) and two In­(III) cations to present the tetragonal geometry structure. The resulting inorganic SBUs are connected through the organic linkers giving rise to a 3D framework and can be described as a highly symmetric (4,4,4)-connected topology network with a Schläfli symbol of (42·83·10)­(42·84).

elements.content: For compound 1, the chirality is derived from the presence of helices. To demonstrate the chiral nature, we randomly selected different bulk crystal samples to measure the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra. As shown in , there are obvious Cotton effects at ca. 230 nm. These results confirm that the bulk sample of compound 1 is homochiral or enantoriched. In addition, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for the two compounds are in good agreement with the ones simulated from single-crystal structural data, which verify the purity of the bulk sample (Figure S4).

elements.content: It is well-known that heterometallic MOFs have excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as luminescent sensing materials as a result of the incorporation of fluorescent organic building blocks. In this work, solid-state luminescent studies were carried out for 1, 2, and ligands ( and S7). The emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are centered at 455 and 438 nm, respectively, exhibiting intense blue luminescent emission (Commission Internacionale d’Eclairage (CIE) coordinates are 0.18, 0.19 for 1, 0.17 0.12 for 2). The similar shape and energy of the emission bands with free 3-Hqlc and H2ox ligands indicate that the luminescence of the compounds originated from the ligands and the red shift may be attributed to the coordination of ligands with metal center.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties of Compounds 1 and 2 

It is well-known that heterometallic MOFs have excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as luminescent sensing materials as a result of the incorporation of fluorescent organic building blocks. In this work, solid-state luminescent studies were carried out for 1, 2, and ligands ( and S7). The emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are centered at 455 and 438 nm, respectively, exhibiting intense blue luminescent emission (Commission Internacionale d'Eclairage (CIE) coordinates are 0.18, 0.19 for 1, 0.17 0.12 for 2). The similar shape and energy of the emission bands with free 3-Hqlc and H2ox ligands indicate that the luminescence of the compounds originated from the ligands and the red shift may be attributed to the coordination of ligands with metal center.

elements.content: When the temperature is decreased from 298 to 77 K, the spectra intensity of the compounds is enhanced and shows a distinctly red-shifted chromic process (455 → 541 nm for 1, 438 → 489 nm for 2). 1 emits intensely light yellow emission (CIE coordinate is 0.42, 0.56) and 2 produces light with CIE coordinate of 0.30, 0.35, which is at the blue end of the region generally considered white. This phenomenon is so-called “luminescence thermochromism”, usually explained by the effect of “cluster centred” interactions. On the basis of heterometallic clusters [K2In­(CO2)2­O3N2Cl5] and [KInO4(CO)10] in the two compounds, the In···K distance and K···K distance are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii for In and K (ca. 1.93 Å for In, 2.75 Å for K), which may tighten the whole skeleton and thus reduce the energy levels between the excited state and the ground state, resulting in red-shifted. Meanwhile, the lifetimes of the compounds enhance markedly at 77 K relative to those at 298 K (298 K: τ = 7.80 μs for 1, τ = 6.81 μs for 2; 77 K: τ = 16.03 μs for 1, τ = 7.70 μs for 2) (Figure S8), due to cold condition is conducive to the rigidity of ligands with reducing the nonradiation decay and collisional quenching. In brief, the compounds show tunable luminescence at 298 and 77 K in the solid state. The obvious change of spectral colors of the compounds indicates they may be potential candidates for application in temperature-sensing devices.

elements.content: In addition, a shows the UV–visible absorption spectra of the two compounds and N719 in ethanol solution, and the corresponding data are listed in . Strikingly, compounds 1 and 2 display a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) absorption band between 330 and 450 nm. Compared with the absorption spectrum of N719, the absorption spectra of compounds 1 and 2 could compensate for that of N719 in the low wavelength region of ultraviolet and blue-violet, especially in the region of 330–450 nm. More importantly, the molar extinction coefficients in the blue-violet region are 49,765 M–1 cm–1 for 1 and 37 507 M–1 cm–1 for 2, which are much higher than that of the ruthenium complex N719. Such higher molar extinction coefficients indicate 1 and 2 possess higher light harvesting ability in this wavelength region compared with N719 and I3 – (25 000 M–1 cm–1). To further explore the feasibility of using the two compounds as cosensitizers in photovoltaic devices for DSSCs, first of all, the absorption spectra of the films are investigated in b. Because of the electronic coupling of the dyes on the TiO2 surface, the absorption of N719 on TiO2 film in the visible light region is remarkably broadened. When N719 is combined with 1 or 2, respectively, the absorption in the region of 350–550 nm on TiO2 film is obviously enhanced. This finding further suggests the two compounds could compensate for that of N719 in the wavelength region of the visible spectrum in the solid state.

elements.content: Second in theory, energy-level matching is extremely crucial for cosensitizer materials used in DSSCs. The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy levels, and the excitation transition energy (E 0–0) can be handled conveniently by equations as follows: HOMO = − ( E ox + 4.4 ) eV ⁣ LUMO = E HOMO + E 0 − 0
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Properties of Compounds 1 and 2 

Second in theory, energy-level matching is extremely crucial for cosensitizer materials used in DSSCs. The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy levels, and the excitation transition energy (E 0-0) can be handled conveniently by equations as follows:     HOMO = -  (   E   ox   + 4.4 )  eV ⁣ LUMO =   E   HOMO   +   E   0 - 0

elements.content: As estimated from the intersection of the normalized absorption and emission spectra, the E 0–0 value is 2.95 eV for 1 and 2.97 for 2. From the onset of the ground state oxidation peak in the cyclic voltammetry (CV), the HOMO values of 1 and 2 are calculated as −5.06 eV and −5.14 eV, respectively. Thus, the LUMO levels of 1 and 2 are estimated to be −2.13 eV and −2.17 eV, respectively. The experimental data are summarized in and the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of 1 and 2 are shown in . For efficient electron injection and regeneration of the photo-oxidized dye, the LUMO level of a sensitizer should lie above the energy level of the conduction band (CB) of the TiO2 semiconductor (−4.40 eV vs vacuum), and its HOMO energy level should lie below the energy level of the I–/I3 – redox couple in the presence of 4-tert-butylpyridine (−4.85 eV vs vacuum). The calculated results show that the energy level of compounds 1 and 2 are higher than that of N719 and the conduction band of TiO2, which bring about an enhanced injection driving force of electrons compared with sole N719. The positive synergistic effect of these compounds and N719 improves the electrons injection efficiency from the LUMO of dye to the conduction band of TiO2. Thus, the suitability of compounds 1 and 2 as cosensitizers in TiO2 based photovoltaic cells can be considered.

To demonstrate the validity of the above assumption for the compounds as cosensitizers, 1/N719 and 2/N719 photoanodes were fabricated with a stepwise cosensitization procedure by sequentially immersing the TiO2 electrode (with thickness of ca. 10 μm) in a separate solution of prepared compounds and N719. The optimum soaking time for the TiO2 photoanode film in compound and N719 was found to be 2 and 12 h, respectively. For comparison purposes, devices sensitized by individual dyes of 1, 2, and N719 were also fabricated under the same experimental conditions. As shown in a, the photocurrent–voltage (J–V) characteristic of the DSSCs devices under illumination (AM 1.5 G, 100 mW cm–2) displayed that the conversion efficiency (η) value of individually N719 sensitized device is 6.61% (with J sc = 16.29 mA cm–2, V oc = 0.70 V, and FF = 0.58). This low performance compared to the previous reports could be due a single thin transparent TiO2 film used in these devices. The individually compounds 1 and 2 sensitized devices exhibited η value of 1.59% (with J sc = 4.31 mA cm–2, V oc = 0.62 V, and FF = 0.59) and 1.50% (with J sc = 3.84 mA cm–2, V oc = 0.61V, and FF = 0.64), respectively. The lower η value for devices sensitized by the compounds sensitizers individually is obviously attributed to their narrow adsorption bands. However, the cell cosensitized by 1/N719 and 2/N719 exhibited the better overall conversion efficiency (η) of 8.07% (with J sc = 17.79 mA cm–2, V oc = 0.74 V, and FF = 0.61) and 7.42% (with J sc = 16.54 mA cm–2, V oc = 0.73 V, and FF = 0.62), which are 22.09% (for 1) and 12.25% (for 2) higher than that of cells individually sensitized by N719. The corresponding cells performances are summarized in . This experimental result indicates that cosensitization of TiO2 photoelectrode with these compounds is an effective way to improve the efficiency of DSSCs.

The higher η value of cosensitized solar cells compared with the individually N719 sensitized device is attributed to the enhanced photovoltaic parameters J sc and V oc. The enhanced J sc value will be discussed in conjunction with the incident photon–to–current conversion efficiency (IPCE) spectra in b, which is related by the equation: J sc = ∫ e ϕ ph . AM 1.5 G ( λ ) d λ where e is the elementary charge and ϕph.AM1.5G is the photon flux at AM 1.5 G, 100 mW/cm2 irradiation. The cell individually sensitized by N719 has a 300–700 nm broad IPCE spectrum, but in the wavelength range of 300–410 nm the intensity decreases, which is due to the competitive light absorption between I3 – and N719. When the prepared compound is used as cosensitizer, this decrease is efficiently inhibited as well as the IPCE spectrum is enhanced in the whole visible region. This is attributed to the fact that cosensitizers have attached on the TiO2 surface and contributed to the electron injection into CB of the TiO2, which is beneficial for light harvesting, electron injection and collection on TiO2. On the basis of the IPCE and the absorption spectra, the cell’s higher J sc in the case of cosensitization is mainly ascribed to better light harvesting in the low wavelength region, where the absorption of N719 is compensated and the competitive light absorption of I3 – is overcome. To rationalize the increase in IPCE, the light harvesting efficiency (LHE) of DSSCs and the absorbed photon-to-current conversion efficiency (APCE) spectra, calculated as IPCE/LHE, are shown in Figure S9a,b. Both of them demonstrated compound 1 or 2, as a cosensitizer, not only has overcome the deficiency of N719 absorption in the region of ultraviolet and blue-violet, but also has enhanced the charge collection efficiency, which should be responsible for the enhanced IPCE and J sc.

The enhanced J sc value will be discussed in conjunction with the incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) spectra in b, which is related by the equation:      J   sc   = ∫  e   ϕ   ph . AM 1.5 G     ( λ )  d λ   where e is the elementary charge and ϕph.AM1.5G is the photon flux at AM 1.5 G, 100 mW/cm2 irradiation. The cell individually sensitized by N719 has a 300-700 nm broad IPCE spectrum, but in the wavelength range of 300-410 nm the intensity decreases, which is due to the competitive light absorption between I3 - and N719. When the prepared compound is used as cosensitizer, this decrease is efficiently inhibited as well as the IPCE spectrum is enhanced in the whole visible region. This is attributed to the fact that cosensitizers have attached on the TiO2 surface and contributed to the electron injection into CB of the TiO2, which is beneficial for light harvesting, electron injection and collection on TiO2. On the basis of the IPCE and the absorption spectra, the cell's higher J sc in the case of cosensitization is mainly ascribed to better light harvesting in the low wavelength region, where the absorption of N719 is compensated and the competitive light absorption of I3 - is overcome. To rationalize the increase in IPCE, the light harvesting efficiency (LHE) of DSSCs and the absorbed photon-to-current conversion efficiency (APCE) spectra, calculated as IPCE/LHE, are shown in Figure S9a,b. Both of them demonstrated compound 1 or 2, as a cosensitizer, not only has overcome the deficiency of N719 absorption in the region of ultraviolet and blue-violet, but also has enhanced the charge collection efficiency, which should be responsible for the enhanced IPCE and J sc.

elements.content: In an effort to understand the enhancement of the V oc value in the cosensitized solar cells and to investigate the kinetics of recombination processes, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of devices based on different photoelectrodes were measured by applying a forward bias of −0.75 V. In the dark, the DSSCs behave as a leaking capacitor. Upon forward bias, the electrons are injected from the FTO substrate into the TiO2, and the film is charged by electron propagation through the mesoscopic TiO2 network. Meanwhile, a fraction of the injected conduction band electrons are lost by the reduction of I3 – ions present in the electrolyte. Therefore, we could measure impedance spectra of DSSCs in the dark to study the electrons recombination from the conduction band of TiO2 to I3 – ions. As shown in a, the three semicircles located in high, middle, and low frequency regions (left to right) of Nyquist plots are attributed to the redox reaction at the Pt counter electrode, the electron transfer at the TiO2/dye/electrolyte interface and charge transfer in the electrolyte (Nernst diffusion). The radius of the large semicircle located in the middle frequency regions in the Nyquist plot increase after cosensitized with the compounds, and the values are in the order of 1/N719 > 2/N719 > N719, which indicates the retardation of the charge recombination between injected electron and I3 – ions in the electrolyte, with a consequent increase of V oc. This appears to be consistent with the larger V oc values sequence. Furthermore, their electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were also measured under standard AM 1.5 G solar irradiation. Under light illumination, the radius of the large semicircle located in the middle frequency regions in the Nyquist plots decrease after cosensitization, and the values are in sequence for 1/N719 < 2/N719 < N719 (b), which indicates a decrease in the electron transfer impedance and an increase in the charge transfer rate at this interface after cosensitization. The above results confirm a higher charge transfer rate and lower charge recombination rate are beneficial for enhancing the performance of DSSCs.

elements.content: Apparently, the strategy of employing the compounds as cosensitizer to decorate the interface in a TiO2 photoanode, developed herein, is an efficient approach toward improving the photovoltaic properties of DSSCs. Taking the structures of the compounds into account, the charge transfer mechanism can be proposed. First, the Ti4+ ion might be coordinated with heterometallic MOFs forming Ti–O coordination bonds due to the existence of lone pair electrons of carboxylic acid groups, which could facilitate the injection of its excited electron into the conduction band of TiO2 film and absorb in the blue-violet spectral region where the N719 absorbs only marginally. Second, heterometallic MOFs contain unit cells, which can be assembled together to form high surface area arrays for photon collection. Besides the dyes tightly anchored onto the TiO2 surface ensuring the efficiency of photocurrent output, the additional dyes adsorbed onto heterometallic MOFs can contribute to the enhancement of J sc. The little difference in performance of cosensitized DSSCs between the two compounds could be due to the changed absorption caused by different structures. The possible photoanode status after cosensitization is shown in . In both cases, a collaborative effort results in markedly enhanced performance.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of Structures for DSSCs

Apparently, the strategy of employing the compounds as cosensitizer to decorate the interface in a TiO2 photoanode, developed herein, is an efficient approach toward improving the photovoltaic properties of DSSCs. Taking the structures of the compounds into account, the charge transfer mechanism can be proposed. First, the Ti4+ ion might be coordinated with heterometallic MOFs forming Ti-O coordination bonds due to the existence of lone pair electrons of carboxylic acid groups, which could facilitate the injection of its excited electron into the conduction band of TiO2 film and absorb in the blue-violet spectral region where the N719 absorbs only marginally. Second, heterometallic MOFs contain unit cells, which can be assembled together to form high surface area arrays for photon collection. Besides the dyes tightly anchored onto the TiO2 surface ensuring the efficiency of photocurrent output, the additional dyes adsorbed onto heterometallic MOFs can contribute to the enhancement of J sc. The little difference in performance of cosensitized DSSCs between the two compounds could be due to the changed absorption caused by different structures. The possible photoanode status after cosensitization is shown in . In both cases, a collaborative effort results in markedly enhanced performance.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have demonstrated that the incorporation of K­(I) proves to be an effective method to grow In­(III)-based crystals and more importantly obtained rare chiral In­(III)–K­(I) heterometallic MOFs 1 via achiral 3-Hqlc ligand in an easily accessible synthetic pathway. Meanwhile both of the two compounds display thermochromic luminescence in the solid state, which have potential application in luminescent sensors. Significantly, devices cosensitized with compounds 1 and 2 yield overall efficiencies of 8.07% and 7.42%, which are 22.09% and 12.25% greater than that of the device containing only N719 (6.61%), respectively. The special performance for heterometallic MOFs as potential light harvesting and energy transferring materials in DSSCs inspires us to further explore the higher photoelectric conversion efficiency in the future. Our studies expand the pool of the chirality of the compounds by achiral units with different cations and pave the way for realizing new applications of heterometallic MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that the incorporation of K(I) proves to be an effective method to grow In(III)-based crystals and more importantly obtained rare chiral In(III)-K(I) heterometallic MOFs 1 via achiral 3-Hqlc ligand in an easily accessible synthetic pathway. Meanwhile both of the two compounds display thermochromic luminescence in the solid state, which have potential application in luminescent sensors. Significantly, devices cosensitized with compounds 1 and 2 yield overall efficiencies of 8.07% and 7.42%, which are 22.09% and 12.25% greater than that of the device containing only N719 (6.61%), respectively. The special performance for heterometallic MOFs as potential light harvesting and energy transferring materials in DSSCs inspires us to further explore the higher photoelectric conversion efficiency in the future. Our studies expand the pool of the chirality of the compounds by achiral units with different cations and pave the way for realizing new applications of heterometallic MOFs.

Single crystals of compound 1 were obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of InCl3 (0.0442 g) and 3-Hqlc (0.0220 g) with a molar ratio of 2:1 in H2O (8 mL) and adjusted to pH = 6.5 with an aqueous solution of KOH. While being stirred for 30 min in air, it was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 120 h. After slowly being cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature (yield 71.2% based on 3-Hqlc). Elemental analysis calcd for [C20H14Cl3N2­O5InK2 (M r : 661.70)]: C, 36.27; H,2.12; N,4.23%; found: C, 36.25; H, 2.16; N, 4.25%. While being stirred for 30 min in air, it was transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 120 h. After being slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature (yield 65.4% based on H2ox). cln_elements.content: It is well-known that heterometallic MOFs have excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as luminescent sensing materials as a result of the incorporation of fluorescent organic building blocks. In this work, solid-state luminescent studies were carried out for 1, 2, and ligands ( and S7). The emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are centered at 455 and 438 nm, respectively, exhibiting intense blue luminescent emission (Commission Internacionale d’Eclairage (CIE) coordinates are 0.18, 0.19 for 1, 0.17 0.12 for 2). The similar shape and energy of the emission bands with free 3-Hqlc and H2ox ligands indicate that the luminescence of the compounds originated from the ligands and the red shift may be attributed to the coordination of ligands with metal center.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties of Compounds 1 and 2 

It is well-known that heterometallic MOFs have excellent luminescent properties and potential applications as luminescent sensing materials as a result of the incorporation of fluorescent organic building blocks. In this work, solid-state luminescent studies were carried out for 1, 2, and ligands ( and S7). The emission spectra of compounds 1 and 2 are centered at 455 and 438 nm, respectively, exhibiting intense blue luminescent emission (Commission Internacionale d'Eclairage (CIE) coordinates are 0.18, 0.19 for 1, 0.17 0.12 for 2). The similar shape and energy of the emission bands with free 3-Hqlc and H2ox ligands indicate that the luminescence of the compounds originated from the ligands and the red shift may be attributed to the coordination of ligands with metal center.
